column3: str
Rawkin is in need of an adventurer with a strong pair of legs.
Pick up the earthenware vase.
Deliver the earthenware vase to the Midlander merchant.
Report to Rawkin.

You've the look of a <If(PlayerParameter(4))>woman<Else/>man</If> who travels. Aye, a <If(PlayerParameter(4))>woman<Else/>man</If> not afraid to do a bit of walking. Might be you could help me with something.
I was to make a delivery of provisions to Ala Ghiri, but it's taken me so long to get everything ready, I'm afraid I'll never get there by the agreed-upon time.
The only way I'd even have a chance at this point is to pass through the Scabbard.
That's assuming, of course, I don't break my legs climbing down the cliffside. By the look of you, I'm betting you could do it without breaking a sweat.
If you'd be willing to help, pick up that vase there and carry it down to Ala Ghiri.
The fastest way to Ala Ghiri is through the Scabbard. Mind your step climbing down the cliff.
Transport the earthenware vase to the specified location at Ala Ghiri before the Midlander merchant grows impatient and calls off the arrangement.
You will have two minutes to complete the task. Should you fail, return to the starting location and begin anew.
Be wary of attacks from enemies, which will sap your strength.
What in the hells is taking him so long? I haven't all day.
deleted
Rawkin's supplies! Thank you, <If(PlayerParameter(4))>miss<Else/>sir</If>, for coming all this way.
Tell him he can expect payment to be delivered in the next few days as promised.
I'm a man of my word. As soon as this shipment reaches its final destination, his payment will be sent at once.
You made it? Thank the gods.

Back in the day, I could've climbed up and down that mountain on one leg if I wanted. I was a soldier, you see, so I had to stay in top physical condition. But war can be cruel. After a few nasty injuries, it was a wonder I made it back here at all.
It was thinking about my time in service, though, that reminded me that soldiers now will be needing any medicine they can get their hands on.
We don't have much, but with everyone pitching in, we can usually sell enough to get by.
Just enough for warm clothes and food to fill our bellies. It's a simple life, but I wouldn't trade it for anything.
